issue_title: Where is the reference position and acceleration and jerk?
issue_contents: I don't see where the position and acceleration and jerk trajectory is taken since the only topic it's subscribed is a geometry_msgs/TwistStamped.
And they are needed by the controller for both feedback (position) and feedforward (acceleration and jerk) terms.
Also the trajectory_publisher seems only to generate a geometry_msgs/TwistStamped setpoint.
Is the position integrated from the velocity (which is btw not really correct)?
Ok, looking at the code I saw that the position is taken from the twist angular (ouch!).
A little info about this in the README would be nice.
I also see there is a not documented controller_msgs::FlatTarget message which can be used to send the complete trajectory up to snap which is nice but it is not documented.
Thanks for the feedback. The twist input was a hack that I put together in the initial stage of the project. I will make a fix on it

issue_title: What are the Equations Used in This Implementaion?
issue_contents: I am trying to find which equations are used to implement the controller in this packahe. In particular, in "Geometric tracking control of a quadrotor UAV on SE (3)" The inputs are collective thrust force, f, and moments M. I beleive it is simple to send f to mavros setpoint. However,  how is the computed moments input, M, mapped to attitude rate setpoints?
Also the, computation of M requires the knowledge of the inertia matrix I, which I don't think is implemented in this package, right? If so, how is that handled?

I explicitly avoided using force and moments for that reason. Moreover, it is not safe to have actuator inputs as a offboard command as the serial connection is prone to packet loss and connection breakages.
The attitude controller is something similar from
. So, the implementation of the controller in this package is based on the report you mentioned, or there are other reports/papers?
Only the attitude controller is based on the link I provided. The rest is based on the papers on the readme.
However, there is no single paper that this implementation points to. The implementation was done carefully to get the best out of controlling the drone aggressively with mavros.
. Do you know of packages for trajectory generations for quadrotors? I am aware of several techniques, but didn’t see an implementation for that.
There are actually quite a lot around. What applicationsare you looking for? I can recommend you a few
I would like to generate fastest feasible position trajectory that goes through some waypoints with re-planning in case of popping obstacles.
Looks like a good start. Have you used that with this package (mavros_controllers)?
I haven't tested it personally, but we have a interface on the MultiDOFJointTrajectory Message as one of the contributors was using it with the geometric_controller.
I have been doing various test with mavros_controllers and found that this value causes the drone to crash in simulation. However, the default value of
does not make the controller unstable and the drone can track the trajectory. I was wondering:
in an Intel Aero RTF and the flight was stable, but I do not want to try the value of 30 after what happens in simulation. See
where I show the performance of both values in simulation.

I came to notice this since a controller I am developing works in simulation but not on the real drone (Intel Aero RTF). However, mavros_controllers works both in sim and real world, in the same drone. I wanted to ask, do you have any ideas why if both controllers work in sim only mavros_controllers work in the real drone?
Thanks for the comments. Does this mean that on the master branch the drone is unable to track the trajectory? I have not tried

is one of the constants that depends highly on the actual hardware. The reason is that we command thrust as normalized thrust values but the actual thrust generated from these normalized thrust values can vary greatly depending on the hardware.
Could you explain more about your controller? The reason the behavior of

is simular between hardware and simulation is that the controller is sending control inputs that are not dependent on the hardware. For example the attitude rate commands are part of the feedback loop of the flight controller, therefore the behavior will be similar. This was a design choice to make it as similar as possible.
Does this mean that on the master branch the drone is unable to track the trajectory?
Yes, at least in simulation in my computer. I did not tried on the real drone.
. Regarding my controller, just like yours it sends thrust and angular velocity commands to the

topic. The values are calculated following using the expressions in your Reference [1], both for the thrust and the desired body-frame angular velocities. So the calculation of thrust is very similar to your geometric_controller, but angular velocity is completely different. Trajectories are generated using differential flatness but some the mass used is that for iris drone
kg. This works in simulation but not on the real drone.
Okay, in that case I would appreciate if you make a fix on the launchfile default gains?

Have you checked if your controller is sending realistic values in terms of jerk when sending angular rates? It might be that your vehicle is simply unable to track the control inputs you are sending.

currently we are running raw3-3 as one of our main robots so imho it is not eol. afaik it uses no cob_driver/control components different from current cob4 robots.
ok, I'll remove raw3-3 from the list of deletable robots.
Regarding the raw_description package: there is a raw4 incoming. The merge requests was stale but it looks like we will find/need some time to work on raw4 soon
then let's keep raw_description. I remove it from the list of deletable packages.

we had a short internal discussion. Right now it looks like we are moving the "rob@work" specific files to our own repository so you don't have to maintain/take over some responsibilities for the rob@work line of robots. This doesn't mean we are not using e.g. cob_driver, but it is likely that we will move all r@w specific stuff to us (in an upcoming PR)
if you ask me, I'm still in favor of
working....but remove it once it's broken - to save the effort of fixing it...
stuff (as one of several) currently prevents a proper
due to the outdated dependency to
raw3-1` which is not-maintained anymore anyway
so if you'd like to "move" raw stuff (description, config and launch files), that'd be ok for me to
that would also mean that IPA takes over support for sold raw's?

but all the other nodes listed above, i.e. "EOL package candidates" - even if unused by supported robots - could remain as long as they are not breaking anything...they have been provided to the ROS community and we do not necessarily know whether anybody else uses them...

One of the points I'm currently running in is, that cob_bringup supplies bringups for a whole load of heterogeneus robots (cob4, raw3 short, raw3 long with arm, raw mini, maybe someday raw4) which all require different dependencies (nothing needs the "cob_mecanum_controller" except the raw-mini, universal robots is only needed for raw3-1 ...).

I wanted to do a minimal install package to install on raw-mini basically where only max. 10% of the (transitive) dependencies of cob_bringup, cob_hardware_config... are actually needed. This didn't work because for example the universal robot stuff --> I created another package "raw_mini_bringup" where I hand-picked dependencies and copied files from cob_bringup so I don't have to depend on cob_bringup.
imho a common package is reasonable for homogeneus robots but for heterogeneous robots it adds a lot of overhead.

The same is true for cob4 which (I assume) is melodic compatible by now, but since raw3-1 is not you cannot move forward until raw3-1 is fixed. so your options are to declare raw3-1 EOL or being stuck on kinetic forever. Splitting up Repostories comes with downsides but allows raw3-1 to be eol without impacting any other robot or needing work (like remove the universal robot driver) which will never be used (since tbh it is probably still running indigo).
Additionally we (ipa) build up a new robot which you never see/hear of until a bunch of random PRs pop up where some mixups happen (like just recently raw-mini != raw4)..
imho a common package is reasonable for homogeneus robots but for heterogeneous robots it adds a lot of overhead.
. This is exaclty the reason why I started the discussion in this issue. Following
statements it would be best to keep
only for Care-O-bot 4 robots and have a separate
repository where all rob@work related launch files and dependencies are moved. If we agree to that, it should be ok to remove the listed robots and packages above (

Hi, I would appreciate not to remove raw3-5 sine we are using it actively. I agree to move it to raw specific repos, but I would really appropriate to keep it in the repos with other dependencies on your packages we are using.

issue_title: Memory error while op3_manager is running
issue_contents: After we fixed OpenCR board we got new error while op3_manager is running.
From the backtrace, I think there is a problem when bulk reading from the process () function of the robotis_controller.
If you modify the product arbitrarily, it is difficult to help debug the problem that may occur.

The robot is moving around a room, controlled by the experimenter using a joystick. Each recorded session is approximately 15 min. The beginning and end of each session is cut and adjusted to that the length is exactly 10 min. There are 4 session recordings per room, with various starting points and trajectories. There is little to no moving objects (including humans) in the room. The robot is directed by the experimenter not to hit any obstacles.
This experiment will provide 32 sessions of 10 min each.
Similar to experiment 1, but humans navigate in the environment. The robot stops often just to observe.
This experiment will provide 16 sessions of 10 min each.

For this experiment, we need to find 8 rooms with different gist (e.g. computer lab, hallway, classroom, lunch room). It would be helpful to have some overall pictures of the rooms (i.e. to share with the dataset). The rooms should be large enough so that we can record 4 sessions of 10 min without the same path.
Here is a list of possible rooms compiled by
Room C1-4016 reservation confirmed. Administration says C1-4113/4115 and C1-4127 are not under their jurisdiction. Will need to find the place to contact.

Resetting of setpoints is currently called in the control loop, at whatever frequency it runs at (10 Hz now). That means that when e.g. using depth hold, diving, then releasing the dive button, the new depth setpoint can be up to 100 ms old, which causes the ROV to move back toward the surface slightly. Should reset setpoints when receiving

issue_title: [Feature] Plug OMPL to Avoidance to open the possibility of using other motion planning algorithms
issue_contents: (Open Motion Planning Library) is a library which contains most of the state-of-the-art motion and path planning algorithms. It's already used in various robotics frameworks, including MoveIt!. Would be interesting to explore the possibility of integrate it with the Avoidance API in order to add other alternatives to the global planner.
is permissive and should set us good to go on the integration.
I am open to discuss this on the next avoidance call.
Note that it can also be installed directly from the ROS deb packages using:
I would be excited to see this moving forward
is this something you have the bandwidth to explore?
Not immediately, but for the upcoming weeks I would be interested in looking into this
which uses OMPL as the planning interface.

do we have requirements that need to be satisfied to move these robots to the main repo?

The point of having things in an experimental repository is that it allows the maintainers to make any potentially breaking changes without prior notice, that it allows for some soak time for new packages and to make them available to users to expose them to use-cases that are not necessarily those of the original author / maintainer.

After a certain amount of time packages stabilise and could be moved to the main repositories. At that point, the regular rules start to apply: semantic versioning, backwards-compatibility guarantees (tick-tock, etc) and all the rest.
Tbh I don't quite get what the problem is with this scheme. If it's lower visiblity then I believe we've addressed that with the creation of
. If you take a look at the repository stats you'll see that that resulted in quite some traffic. My experience with

If it's the fact that experimental repositories are not released and have to be build from sources: I would say that anyone doing anything serious with ROS will have a workspace and runs Catkin once in a while anyway. With a proper
and / or documentation it's peanuts to build the packages. But if we really want to we
create releases for the experimental repository as well.
were submitted -- and just for the few support pkgs that were contributed in the past few months -- I think shows that letting things sit here for some time is not such a bad thing.
Perhaps we could quantify what "a certain amount of time" is. That could take away some of the apparent 'arbitrary-ness' of when things do get migrated.

issue_title: Convex Hull and KF show different mean offset
issue_contents: I added the time translator to a cpp driver for xsens IMUs. It seems to work fine, but when I plot the duration between the translated stamp in the header of my IMU messages vs. their receive time in a analyzer node, the convex hull-based approach shows a consistently higher value. In contrast, for the KF, even values < 0 are sometimes reported, which is implausible (as that indicates the message has been received before it was generated on the device ;) ). The offset for the update function is set to 0.0 for my testing.
Convex hull (diff between consecutive imu stamps blue, diff between imu stamp and receive time in test node red):
Note how here, the red plot dips below 0 quite frequently.
Is this expected behavior? What's the recommended approach to use?
, thanks for trying out this library.
I do not fully understand your plots. Can you give me more input?
I assume the blue lines are the deltas of consecutive timestamps after translation with CH or KF.
For the red I'm at a loss because I don't know what your analyzer node is.

Regarding your issue-question, whether there can be a mean offset between KF an CH output: yes, it is very much expected. This is because the KF's mean output is based on an averaged delay while the CH at a minimal delay, which is always smaller or equal. As a consequence they deviate the more the larger the random transport delay's range is (roughly by half of the range's diameter it).

The fact that the CH is larger her indicates that we are looking with a flipped perspective on this phenomenon (e.g. by looking somehow at how much the translators subtract from the receive time, which is larger for the CH because it can observe more of the actual transport delay and consequentially removes more). To be more specific I'd need to know more about the red values.

This difference in mean is not a problem in practice because when estimating the remaining delay after translation this difference is observable and gets removed as a part of the estimated delay. Of course this means that the estimated delay depends on which translation algorithm is used(!). But that is inevitable given the original problem (AFAIK).

Thanks for the fast reply! The blue lines are indeed the header stamp differences between consecutive stamps after translation. The red line is the header timestamp (as provided by the translator) subtracted from the receive stamp in the analyzer node:

I guess it's a matter of convention if the subtraction should be reversed and thus signs flipped :) Of course, this additionally contains the transport latency of ROS topic communication (from IMU node to the analyzer node generating the output).
What I'm aiming for is a little better understanding of how to choose CH vs KF and also how to choose a value for the
param. As visible from the (red) plots, it seems there is some kind of clock divergence that resets every ~8s.

Makes sense to me that the offset is observable in principle, but it can still be quite challenging to calibrate it, depending on hardware constraints. An "easy" option that comes to mind would be using a global shutter cam with h/w trigger, a microcontroller time-synced to the PC and kalibr. If you have any hints about other options I'm open to suggestions :)
And the "analyzer node" is just some node running on the same computer as the IMU node that you wrote to analyze the timestamps of the IMU?
If it is on the same computer, then that is indeed a confusing fact about this KF approach that you found.
With this algorithm,  in average, the delta between the timestamp after translation and the receive time is close to zero (by design)!

But the translated component has a smaller random delay component (it removes partially the randomness from the timestamp - that is the purpose of the algo.). Hence, the translated time must be sometimes in the future of the receive time (negative red in your case).

The KF does not even try to guess the average transport delay from the IMU (in your case) to the computer. This average transport delay (temporal offset) would fix this this confusing observation (the red line would be increased by this positive constant).

The fact that the red line is not in average zero is actually because you don't compute that in the IMU node but in a separate node that receives a little later, i.e. the average of the red signal is pretty precisely the average transport delay from IMU node to analyzer node. The noise of the red signal is the sum of the two random transport delays, IMU to IMU node + IMU node to analyzer node, while the first is actually only visible, because it got removed by the KF or CH (the removed noise can be retrieved by comparing with the receive time -- after all it is the one that got corrected in the first place).

Regarding this 8s period I can only guess. Maybe the CPU load or the USB bus's load (assuming it is USB) is for some reason of this periodicity? Or it actually comes from the IMU where there is a periodic change in the processing delay (the transport should not be IMO).

Ah, maybe, if it is USB, then actually it is because of the poling rhythm of the USB (prior to 3.0). When you poll with a fixed rate with a non-integer ratio compared to the emission frequency then the delay should vary periodically. That could be it. Maybe you can find the current USB polling rate and see whether it can explain the 8s period.

For CH vs. KF: I would use CH (while switching about every few hundred seconds) for nice clocks that do not have strong higher order drifts. For very cheap clocks or those that have to sustain aggressive temperature changes the KF is better but might need tuning.
Observing is the average offset is hard for an IMU. And yes, Kalibr + trigger or shutter signal could be a good practical approach to this.

One more thing about finding this overage offset: Please note that it is rarely useful (alone). Typically, the pairwise temporal offsets between sensors + actuators is relevant while the offset w.r.t. to CPU can often be ignored. Of course, this changes if some sensor to CPU offsets are already known. Then getting the others can be efficient to achieve the goal.
Thanks again for your library. We ran
to visualize the performance of our time translation.
Our system consists of various sensors, event stamped on an Arduino 101, and transmitted via USB to a Braswell CPU:
Given this plot our conclusions are:
, thank you for this beautiful plot of a really bad clock (skew changes) and transport randomness - this looks like the perfect justification for this library ;).
Yes, I agree with both 1. and 2.. You might additionally want to try an even shorter living
Given the p lot I would actually go for a short living

As you can nicely see, the Kalman alternative (with its current parameters) changes its mean offset from the minimum delay boundary (lower bounds of the red curve) over longer periods of time significantly: its smaller when the lower bound is rising and larger when it is falling and the difference seems to be around 2 ms. This would be a systematic error for some time you cannot calibrate away.

Systematic errors (over longer periods) are less extreme on the CH and you can make them even smaller with a slightly shorter switching period at the expected expense of slightly higher short term errors.
Which you pick between these two should depend on what you do with the timestamps later.
As for what this says about the underlying problems, things are a bit less clear -- unfortunately.
The random delays could be the USB delays ('assuming it still gos through a USB -- couldn't fully figure that out from the image)
But it could also be stemming (partially) from some buffering on receiver or transmitter side (I'm not sure about both, the
). So maybe one can reduce those with a little digging.
Of course thanks to the transmit timestamp you can correct for them quite nicely with the timestamp translation approach.
A delay of 20ms however, can still affect your system because you still have to wait this extra delay for your data, which may or may not be a problem.

The quite fast change of skew could indicate larger temperature changes on the micro controller. Can you easily access the temperature? I could imagine that the changing air currents and possibly the changing (relative) sun bearing can change the temperature quite quickly for drones.
Thanks again. I hope it's also a good reference for other users.
I hope the bad clock is not the only issues. Because otherwise the whole setup is kind of bad.
I'll try and document here the following things to seperate issues on the setup.

issue_title: Discussion on unifying behavioral differences between local planner and global planner
issue_contents: I have been looking into understand how global planner works, and it seems that the implementation is quite different compared to the local planner.
This alone is not too bad, but the real problem is that the general interaction with the firmware becomes different. The recent failsafe features in

Re-implementing the same behavior doesn't seem quite straight forward as both planners are tightly integrated into their use cases. Moreover, it would be hard to maintain both cmdloops to show the same behavior everytime there is something changing in the
One solution can be that there is a single node that handles all interaction with mavros including the failsafe features, while global and local planners only have planner specific functions.
I would like to implement something like a
which does the following things, on top of
Please give any inputs or comments regarding this issue. I would be willing to implement this, but this would need to bring changes on both
Therefore I wanted some consensus from the community if this is something we want, or worth considering, or if it is too early to move in this direction.

Modularizing these things would also make it easier to use things like OMPL, or quickly sketch out new planners and test them. Maybe a semi-global planner will be the future? (To be honest, that's what the current local planner pretty much is...)
Obviously, I'm biased by my thesis though

I agree. The direction I would like to see the avoidance repo go, is that anybody should be able to easily plug in their planner to the avoidance. This unloads people from tightly integrating their stuff to PX4. but this will be far in the future.

issue_contents: , local planner use the parameter from PX4 firmware.

However, there isn't limitation for these parameters, as i test, the MPC_XY_CRUISE get from firmware is 10, even i already set the speed to 1 in mission mode. The local planner use 10 as param_mpc_xy_cruise,thus cause avoid obstacle fail.
Check and add limitation for local_planner parameters, not just use firmware parameters.

Long term, we want the local_planner (and the global_planner) to be completely transparent when there are no obstacles. This means that it should fly at the speed given by the MPC_XY_CRUISE during mission mode. Only once there are obstacles does the planner slow down the vehicle, usually due to the planned path being outside of the FOV of the camera.

So, the correct solution is to reduce MPC_XY_CRUISE. Otherwise there is a different behavior when obstacle avoidance is running or not, even when there are not any obstacles. MPC_XY_CRUISE can be updated live during flight, for testing.

From the PX4 Firmware code we can see:  The MPC_XY_CRUISE is Normal default horizontal velocity in AUTO modes (includes Mission/RTL / hold / etc). But when we perform the mission task, we can modify the speed.  The speed is not set by MPC_XY_CRUISE.
In obstacle avoidance, we can't judge the speed by just using this parameter（MPC_XY_CRUISE）.

I've gotten confused with this speed set by the mission item before. Back then, the speed set in the mission item was not being used by PX4. I just tested in SITL, and this seems to no longer be the case, so I guess you are correct
So the speed set in mission mode isn't MPC_XY_CRUISE, that's why i set the speed to 1 in mission mode, but still get 10 from PX4 firmware.

This makes sense, yes. We need to check the speed of the mission item and use that. It will be a little bit complicated since we need to find which messages they are from, but I agree it should be done to make it consistent with flying non-avoidance missions.

issue_contents: Currently the planner only looks for flat surfaces to land. It would be good if it could also (or instead) choose a visual target (eg. AprilTag, ChiliTag,
etc) and land on that instead.
For better integration maybe this could use some kind of identifier from the mission item itself, and only land on a tag with the same ID.
Do we have any progress on the visual target for safe landing ? Please let me know.
What was your approach to replace the flat surface with the tags or markers ? I want to implement the tag functionality with the safe landing planner node.
It would be roughly like this:
If you are going to contribute this upstream I'd be happy to provide additional guidance as you go.
contents_details_more: Start with existing safe landing planner
Descend until laser range finder gives the desired altitude above ground (instead of point cloud data from depth camera)
Fly the same grid pattern as the safe landing planner, but at each grid point, instead of looking for a flat area, check if the camera image contains the April/aruco/whatever tag you are looking for.
Calculate tag location based on laser altitude and angle (from camera focal length)
Reposition so that the vehicle is directly above the calculated tag location. Repeat until within required accuracy bounds
Descend, while keeping the calculated tag location directly below.

issue_contents: What I'm looking for is a baseline implementation that we can then tune interactively with the Autonomy team and Stefan.
Suppose I have 3 sensors. One pointing straight ahead, one 15° to the right and the other 15° to the left (345°).
would have a value of 15 and I would expect 3 values in
to be used/valid. When I look at
, where is "center"? I assume this is what
Also, the array length is even, making the left/right values asymmetric.
It's in the local frame, not the vehicle frame. We should probably make that more clear in the message definition.
Ok, how do I find "straight ahead" from this?
And how would the above, 3-sensor example be represented in the array?
It's in the local frame, not the vehicle frame. We should probably make that more clear in the message definition.
and "in front of the sensor " as vehicle relative. Clearly quite a lot of docs improvements needed here.
This is how I interpret it according to what is written:

Suppose I have 3 sensors. One pointing straight ahead, one 15° to the right and the other 15° to the left (345°). increment or increment_f would have a value of 15 and I would expect 3 values in distances to be used/valid. When I look at distances, where is "center"? I assume this is what angle_offset is telling me?
I don't know if I'm "right" but my understanding, but
I guess we need to know how it has been implemented to progress.
found my description useless. Note in both cases I assume that the frame is the vehicle heading = 0 degrees. NOT North = 0degrees.
Case 1 - old style message where the points are evenly spread relative to front of vehicle. Not very flexible.

Case 2. new message. Distance array is for a chunk of data at starting at some angle relative to the 0 degree position (front of vehicle) with fixed increment spacings. May take multiple messages to cover the whole range, and this allows different messages to have different spacing of sensors.
Caveat, I guess either all messages for sensor have to be sent in a burst so they are all relative to the same heading. Probably should add something to allow better sync.
- The table sums up the possible states of the OA system. My idea is to show the user a single icon that captures both if the OA is enabled and healthy.
We also would need a switch in QGC to enable OA that basically sets  COM_OBS_AVOID to 1  and
CP_DIST to 5 to enable it and COM_OBS_AVOID to 0 and CP_DIST -1 to disabled it
I think you guys are making this more complicated than it is. In the case of a forward facing camera with a 90deg wide view (45 left, 45 right) a message would look like:
If the camera is facing directly backwards

I found a Lidar simulator that likes to deliver it's 360 data in CCW order. I'd also like to note that the left-to-right increment is not necessarily a hard requirement. That's just the positive increment direction. On ArduPilot a negative increment means left (CCW).
So, this camera data would read in the distance values, index zero first  on the right:
In the case of a forward facing camera with a 90deg wide view
What if you have 4 of those pointing in all 4 directions? Will it send 4 messages, one for each or will it consolidate all into one message?

My current implementation assumes one single message. A subsequent message would override the previous one (the previous distance slots). There is no way to identify which sensor a message is coming from.
What implementation? In the case of Ardupilot, you can receive multiple messages and they "add" internally. No need to identify them other than angle and increment
you can receive multiple messages and they "add" internally

Add to where? What GCS does this? How do you keep track of angle slots given that you have unpredictable (floating point) increment values that can be different from sensor to sensor? I guess I could keep an array and arbitrarily set its length to 360 and "fit" the distances within those slots. That would work. But I still don't know how to handle a case of a sensor going bad and stop sending data. I would not be able to detect that. Any distance set on its set of distances would get "stuck". Again, I could again add code to
these values out over time. Either way, none of this is documented.
Please take a look at the implementation.
The Ardupilot and PX4 approaches are very different here.

In PX4, if there are onboard distance sensors that are configured for collision prevention, it will use those sensors and then publishes a single fused OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message. This will be fused with the data received from an external OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message. The idea is then that that the GCS could use this to display the data that the FCU is
using to avoid, without having to attempt to replicate perfectly the internal fusion algorithm.

support multiple sources sending OBSTACLE_DISTANCE messages. They need to be fused externally before sending them in. Unfortunately it would require some fairly major architecture changes to support this.
, it seems it would be quite a pain to replicate the multi-message fusion inside of the GCS.
Would it work on AP side to publish the internal data as a new OBSTACLE_DISTANCE message for the GCS to consume? It looks like it would be fairly easy, there are already the
arrays which just need to be put into a message and published.
it looks to me like the MAVLink message definition doesn't allow for negative increments.
"If greater than 0 then this value is used instead of the uint8_t increment field."
So either we need to update that description, or shouldn't support negative increments.

ahh yes, true. The negative is only supported on the float version. Description needs to be updated. It was something I just recently added though so I doubt PX4 supports it yet. Are you willing to update the docs or would you like me/someoneElse to?
Could you update the docs? I'll get support into PX4 ASAP

Or you might "fill in" more values at different increments - but values still centred around 35 or 35.
increment = 0, increment_f=15, angle_offset=345, just fill in first three values.
or send multiple messages, or whatever.

issue_contents: Is it possible to check the PX4 Avoidance UML model ?
I mean if it could be available in order to understand more in deep the structure of the software.I'd like to study it.

We don't have any. In the README you can find the master theses that the Local and Global Planners are based of. However there as been a lot of development since then so some algorithm steps described in the thesis are gone from the code and some implementations in the code are not described in the thesis.
Finally I've got the following UML diagrams from a software called Visual Paradigm.
I don't know how accurate they are because they have been generated automatically.
At first glance the reversing process is very easy (menu tools->code->instant reverse) but I think that could be optimized.
Anyway they could be used as rough reference .

The planner basically needs to things in order to work:

Try to do rostopic list and then look at the rates at which you are getting this information. If either of them is not published or way too slow you will see the mentioned warnings. If the pointcloud is missing, you might have problems with the gazebo plugin or model of the camera/drone. If the stuff from mavros is missing, you might have wrong fcu url or did not build the firmware correctly.

I am getting the data on /mavros/local_position/pose topic but not on pointcloud. I've installed the gazebo using apt ros-kinetic-gazebo-* , which installs gazebo-7. I'm using this drone/camera model from the launch file -
. I've uninstalled and re-installed the gazebo-7 but the issue was same. Am i missing something here?

When the autopilot is in LAND mode (and maybe some others) it sends a goal=[x, y, NAN]. On the local planner side this goal through the whole calculation resulting in a cost-matrix full of NANs etc. This does not really affect the performance, as we are not doing any avoidance maneuvers in land/takeoff mode and the planner recovers as soon as it gets a valid goal again. But still this should be fixed, also because processing NANs is slow and should be avoided anyway.
Test: If you display the /cost_matrix topic in RVIZ,  the matrix will turn yellow if it contains NANs.

This is not a bug, meaning that NAN in PX4 is a not controlled output. In the case of a land, PX4 doesn't control the z position but only velocity. If we set the position we will never be able to land properly given the error in z.
The only thing we can do is set the goal position in z to zero but then we need to ignore that position on the waypoint generation side.

yes, that is what I mean. I think it needs some discussion on how to best handle it, but processing all NANs through the local_planner is not a good solution in my opinion. It is not urgent, I just wanted to note it here.

issue_title: [Global Planner] Unable to cope with RTL & LAND mode
issue_contents: Global planner on the master is not able to handle with RTL & Land mode since /mavros/trajectory/desired topic comes in does not contain valid data, no frame_id
while the local planner could work with RTL & Land mode from the firmware.
In RTL or Land mode the vehicle should return to launch with avoiding obstacles or land.
Wouldn't the correct expected behavior be that the vehicle RTLs or Land? Why do you want it do hover at the current position?
This is related to how the setpoints are handled in global planner. This was partly the reason I was trying to port the state machine into global_planner in
For RTL and Land, it seems its waypoint is given well however, in the callback
It doesn't seem it is blocked to use but why the global planner is not able to cope it?
Do you have a log? Where does it stop following the land point?
When RTL is enabled, It seems path finder behind is unable to find a path with altitude difference (it is lower than planner's max_altitude_ though)
In my case, mission is at 10m -> RTL 30m, reducing rtl_return_alt to 0 enabled return but still unable to land, it's z position is nan for point_1 but point_2 has all valid point.
Landing with the planner while finding safe path not available since global planner is using altitude prior to assess risk of the cell
And also would not allow altitude estimation drift & flying over declining surfaces which can be often found in real world.
I think this alt_prior need to be improved or replaced with better concept or so.
Partial solution for RTL issue is at

issue_title: improve position estimate by feeding pressure sensor data  through IMU sensor fusion board
issue_contents: that improves the accuracy of the IMU.

The sensor fusion chip is sensor agnostic meaning that it can take data from most sensors as long as the sensor is I2C register readable. We can therefore  feed the sensor fusion algorithm data from the
to give us a more precise position estimate. kriswiner has a nice
, this might be a good place to start implementing this.
's ROV project intended for use in the

Including data from the pressure sensor in the fusion algorithm is not really a matter of improving the accuracy for pressure, but rather to feed the algorithm more data to allow it give us a more precise position/attitude estimate.
You are right, I'll clarify the issue.

issue_title: Update controller interface with option for pose inputs
issue_contents: Should be possible to ask the controller node "Hey go to this particular position and orientation".
In particular, we should consider which, if any, need the

The claw_stepper only has directional control at the moment. It could be useful to give a command to perform a given amount of rotations/steps for spinning valves and such. It could be especially useful when attempting to level the OBS when we know how many rotations are needed to level the platform.
This is a good idea. Will be practical to be able to ask for x number of degrees (or radians, if you're a nerd).
Steppers should have individual speed control. The speed requirements for the claw stepper and the vertical stepper are different, so individual speed control would be nice.

issue_title: Maximum JPEG image size may be reached
issue_contents: The current maximum number of bytes for a JPEG-encoded image is 32768 when exporting a rosbag to HDF5:

This led to errors lately because some images were going over this limit. The script could be adapted to automatically increase the shape of the data, similarly to what is done here for the time dimension:
Right now, we just use a bigger value of 40000.

issue_title: Find a repository to publish the data
issue_contents: We are likely to have around 60 GB of data for the final dataset, and we would need a web host to make this data publicly available. Aside hosting the files on our department's server at Université de Sherbrooke, there are several alternatives:
Ideally, the data repository should be in the field of machine learning.

issue_title: Select best 10min of data based on stats
issue_contents: Add the option do extract the best 10 min window of data from each 15min session based on the statistics of the session. This will allow us to get the best possible quality data from the recordings.
This is to avoid getting data from sessions where the beginning or the end of the recording are not up to quality. This can be due to increased message drops caused by the system being overloaded.
Also add the option to give variable length windows based on a quality threshold. This way we can get the most data possible while still respecting a certain standard.
Added the dropped messages graph over time generation option in commit

. From the graphs (like shown below for S2 of E2 C1CORR), most of the dropped messages appears after a certain time (700 seconds in this case). Is this due to a memory limit that we imposed on ROS? If so this is an easy fix. Curiously, I did not see this behaviour, for the first recording.
Rosbag cropping now added to dataset creation process in
Next step would be to allow automatic mode based on quality threshold instead

In some locations (most notably tunnels), the magnetometer gives out unreliable data. Usually, this is marked by very low values (all axis are <20uT) and/or being close to thick cement walls. Note that, when the robot is still, the magnetometer data is also very stable, it seems that the sole source of the faulty data is the environment (thick wall, outside electronics, etc).
I noticed the same problem even in C1 FLOOR3. It seems, that most buildings on campus act as Faraday cages.
contents_details_more: Fix the problem by setting a threshold value for when to use the magnetometer in orientation for example.

Or, simply let the occasional unreliable data serve as part of the training data. After all, if we provide the angular velocity data, the machine should be able to realize by sensory fusion that magnetometer data is faulty and should be ignored.

issue_contents: We want to add language to our dataset in order for the robot to convey it's state in words. This will make it easier to interpret for humans and will provide a bridge for IGLU. We will focus on
he has. In other words, he will say "Moving Forward", but not "I see an apple".

I propose that for each recoding we generate a YAML (.yml) file that will be used to in turn generate a rosbag containing only the language messages. After that, we fuse the language and original rosbags together.
Here is an example of a YAML file in this context.
In this case, the robot only moved forward at times 0.0, 15.1 and  65.7 for durations 14.0, 49.2 and 10.5 respectively.

Some actions could be populated automatically in the YAML file (for example, Forward, turn, move, stop, etc) since they have implicit and clear associations to certain values (Forward movement is implied when both wheels are activated with same power). However, some higher level actions will have to be added by humans to the YAML file. For example, "wandering" doesnt have and implicit associated value in the rosbags so we will have to set it ourselves.
For the manual annotations, we could use rqt_bag tool:
We don't actually see the video (only thumbnails), but it is easy to navigate the timeline for useful sensors (e.g. gyroscope and motor velocities). We also have direct access to the timestamps.
Since we can generate videos from sensors, we could also use the ELAN annotation tool:
It is supposed to support multiple synchronized media sources. Some other projects are using this:
Here is a graph of possible labels , those label dependencies and their possible attributes
contents_details_more: Add function of writing to YAML file
Add rules for tags other than Move and Stop
Write code to generate rosbag from YAML file
Add language rosbag fusion to main rosbag part of dataset creation process
Add manually or create tools to add missing tags (ex: Wander, slipping)

issue_code:
exit               Exits the program.
re                 Refreshes the screen.
b                  Move to previous page.
n                  Move to next page.
page [index]       Move to page [index].
list               View list of pages.
new                Clears data of current page and initializes page.
copy [index]       Copy data from page [index].
set [value]        Sets value on cursor [value].
save               Saves changes.
play               Motion playback of current page.
playboth [index]   Motion playback of current page with [index] mp3.
g [index]          Motion playback of STP[index].
name               Name for current page or changes the name of current page.
time               Change time base playing.
speed              Change speed base playing.
w [index]          Overwrites data from STP[index] with STP7.
i                  Inserts data from STP7 to STP0. 
                   Moves data from STP[x] to STP[x+1].
i [index]          Inserts data from STP7 to STP[index]. 
                   Moves data from STP[index] to STP[index+1].
m [index] [index2] Moves data from [index] to [index2] step.
d [index]          Deletes data from STP[index]. 
                   Pushes data from STP[index] to STP[index-1].
mlr [index]        Mirror the left side value to the right of STP[index]. 
mrl [index]        Mirror the right side value to the left of STP[index]. 
ms [index]         Switch the values between left and right of STP[index]. 
on/off             Turn On/Off torque from ALL actuators.
on/off [index1] [index2] ...  
                   turns On/Off torque from ID[index1] ID[index2]...

issue_contents: The direct control module is activated to capture the object from the ground and the object is captured. Then we move to the walking position. Walking with modulating. We run the object to the target we want to drop/leave . To put the object on the target, we need to switch back to the Direct control module. But in the case, the robot puts all its motors in the starting position. That's when he drops the object on the floor. He sits down quickly. We can't drop the object on target. How can we did it?
I need your answers to the questions below to help you.
1 -Does it continue to appear every changing the module?
When you move from the Walking Module to the DirectControl Module, the robot releases the object. There is no problem switching from DirectControl to Walking.
2- What if you changed the module in different situations?
There is problem when we pass to walking module from direct control module or action module.
Changing to the direct control module from walking module,  all joints take the starting position.
4-Are you updating your goal position in other modules?

We have different goals for each module. For example, in the Walking module the goal is to walk for 3 seconds. In the DirectControl Module, the target will drop the object to the table we are in front of after 3 seconds.
The goal position I mentioned means the goal position of dynamixel. It is a value to put as result variable in process function of each module.
The direct_control_module and action_module move based on this value, so that each joint can move to 0 degrees when changing the mode If the goal position is initialized.
contents_details_more: Does it continue to appear every changing the module?
What if you changed the module in different situations?
Does it happen in all joints?
Are you updating your goal position in other modules?
: updating result from goal position of dxl
: making syncwrite data to dxl using result variables

issue_title: Little matched points when running localization
issue_contents: I'm trying the localization package using imu, odom and Lidar. But, it seems that the matched points is very little when I move the robot around(less than 10 points).

I noticed that there're tens of matched points in your demo video, and the localization is accurate. But, in my case, the robot sometimes gets lost and cannot recover due to insufficient matched points.
Any thought on that? Thanks a lot in advance.
I guess you are using 3D LIDAR like Velodyne.
Such kinds of LIDARs provide pointcloud in which its horizontal scan is split into several pointcloud messages.
parameter should be increased to the number of the pointcloud messages reconstructing a full horizontal scan.

I am currently working on a Kubernetes cluster using ROS melodic (for specific project reasons melodic needs to be used). As the ros master is a single point of failure, I want to make it redundant and came across your software. Thanks for sharing it!
In the cluster every node can directly address every node via its IP.
Each ros master is running in a Kubernetes pod, this means each container inside the pod shares storage and network. In total there are three containers for each pod running the following commands:
The container image is created as following:
Note: Broadcast and multicast get enabled before start.
The master discovery seems to work correctly:
Also I do not see any errors in the sync output:
For test purpose there is realsense (camera) node which is publishing data from the camera. This will create a certain amount of topics and the realsense randomly registers add one of the masters.
At master one, I see the following topics:
At master 2 there is only a small subset of the topics available:
It looks like there seems to be some synchronization but it seems to not work completely.
Do you see any problems in the set up? Is there some output/log files I should consult?
is there a reason why you use
It could be a problem if ROS_MASTER_URI and ROS_IP has not the same entry, since they are not resolved by master sync.
For more output you can run master_sync with
(run twice, if you do no see debug output)

is done, because the hostname is per default not resolvable in kuberenetes. I did so to achieve that the IP address is used instead of the hostname. Which seems to work if I check the discover output:

For the realsense this is not done . Instead its ROS_HOSTNAME is set to the name (in this case "realsense") of a "headless kubernetes service" which is pointing to the pod and the container contained.

With just one master this is done also for the ros master. But with multiple masters the service "ros-master" should resolve to all instances and connection will be randomly distributed between the masters. Following this, it should be transparent for a client if a master goes down or comes up, if all masters are synched.
Therefor, I used the trick of setting the ROS_IP in order to not use the ROS_HOSTNAME.
Just as a side note: With just one standard ros master everything is working as expected.
I tested with setting the ROS_MASTER_URI to
. Unfortunately this did not solve the problem.
I will try with investigating the logs in more details this evening with the additional log level!
At which frequency are the masters synchronized?
for all ROS-Nodes (roscore, master_discovery, master_sync and realsense)?
By default the changes of local roscore are checked at 1 Hz. If changes are detected the synchronization process will be initialized. You can change the check rate in

ROS_MASTER_URI is for all nodes (except master)

There is a kubernetes service running which allows the nodes to connect to the master(s) behind that host name. And each host is using export ROS_IP=$(hostname -i), to set their ROS ip address in order to communicate with other nodes.

checks the md5sum of remote topic with local one. I guess

(2.) is one of the problems with synchronization of remote nodes. Depending on ros-networks (multiple
nodes) and timings the remote nodes could be stopped by roscore (multiple registration of nodes with same name.) It could also lead to visualization issues in
do to dleays while tests for running state of the node.
You should start roscore, master_discovery and master_sync on each pod/container. This is the scenario what the multimaster was designed for.
I did not understand that the ROS nodes were started in another container than master_dsicovery. So the fix I did is for this problem not relevant.
Is there a reasen why you start the ROS-Nodes in different container as roscore and master_discovery?
Thanks. With setting it as local variable it works!
After all the setup is the following:

Inside the K8S cluster there is one pod for each ros program (node). Each of them is connecting to the ROS master(s). Because the ROS master is per default not backed up nor redundant, I was looking for running a redundant ROS master. Each instance of the ros master will run in their own pod. In that pod now the roscore, ros_master_sync and ros_master_discovery are running for each ros master.

But all of the other nodes never know to which master they connect, as they are connecting via a service which randomly resolves to one of the ros masters. If old of them are in synch and one crashes for what reason so ever, it should be transparent to the nodes, as they will just register or request a topic from one of the other masters, which should by in synch.

It looks that it is running now, but apparently not 100% reliable. A colleague told me that he encountered some problems, apparently some topics have not been available. I am right now trying to reproduce the issue.

WORKDIR 'catkin_ws/src'

    rosdep update && \
    rosdep install -i --as-root pip:false --reinstall --from-paths multimaster -y 

WORKDIR '..'

RUN /bin/bash -c '. /opt/ros/melodic/setup.bash; catkin build fkie_multimaster'

issue_contents: Add ROS level API for the following
Although I like having the various information regarding the battery state as individual topics, it might make more sense to bundle them into the existing
message for the battery temperature since
I think this is a bug of laser_geometry...
Actually, it seems that laser_max_range is deprecated in the code but is still used when high_fidelity is false. Do you need that parameter ?

This looks like you're spinning a laser relatively quickly. Enabling high_fidelity projection will enable interpolated position of the laser for each point sampled in the scan.  Without that option it transforms all points in a scan at a single point in time. With that flag off, it is much lower computation for the transformation but it trades off the assumption that the motion of the laser is negligable during the duration of the laser scan.
If you think this is actually a bug. please provide a way to reproduce it such as a relevant bag file and reference material for the enviornment, and the commands to reproduce the display.
are the topics where I see this issue.
I had a very similar issue with a tilting lidar, where I would get a complete sphere at max range of the lidar. I simply fixed it by introducing another range filter dropping points max range -1.
Soft stops are currently a quadratic P-term.
Need some damping to keep things from freaking out.
, is looking to address this issue. Any suggestions are appreciated!

issue_contents: I am unable to load ARNI plugins in rqt_gui since it is empty.
Please help me to solve this problem.
Have you installed it from source or via a package manager? Any more information you can give, do other plugins work?
Yes, I installed it from source. Yes, Other plugins are working fine.
when i launch rosrun rqt_gui rqt_gui, I am getting these errors. Please help me to solve this problem.

[ERROR] [1509878772.441464399]: Skipping XML Document "/home/sumit/catkin_ws/src/arni-master/arni_rqt_detail_plugin/plugin.xml" which had no Root Element.  This likely means the XML is malformed or missing.

[ERROR] [1509878772.441574240]: Skipping XML Document "/home/sumit/catkin_ws/src/arni-master/arni_rqt_overview_plugin/plugin.xml" which had no Root Element.  This likely means the XML is malformed or missing.

RosPluginProvider._parse_plugin_xml() plugin file "/home/sumit/catkin_ws/src/arni-master/arni_rqt_overview_plugin/plugin.xml" in package "arni_rqt_overview_plugin" not found
Which version of ROS are you running? Also I assume you have checked out the latest commit of this repo, right?
I am using ROS kinetic 16.04 version.

Okay, and ARNI is up to date as well I hope? Also to make sure this is not a build problem, can you rebuild your workspace and verify that the error still occurs (commands below)? Note down any errors and paste them here.
But still it is the same error (above). Default rqt will open but it is empty.
And there is no arni-overview in Introspection. Because it is showing the above error.
I have attached two images. Please look at it.
What do you mean by "rqt" is empty?
For all I know /statistics_node exists as soon as /statistics_host exists. Look into the output of the nodeinterface, possibly a dependency is missing or some other error occured..
Okay, Thank you so much. I will check with that.
I just ran into a similar issue too. I followed the directions on the tutorial
which concludes with running rqt_gui and enabling the "Topic Monitor" plugin.  However the
field is not in the list of topics as it is shown on the example image.  I'm running ros-kinetic on a virtual machine and also installed pyqtgraph from source as directed.
and see if it is listed there. In my case it returns
as well  thus I believe this is a bug in the topic monitor.
I checked the rostopic list, but there is no /statistics_node.
now it is showing /statistics_node in rostopic list but not in the topic monitor.

This is good. I cannot explain why the topic monitor does not show not, I assume this is a bug unrelated to ARNI. I don't have the time to report the bug but if you want to try to contact the maintainers of the topic monitor .
I'm not sure that the problem is necessarily in the Topic Monitor Plugin.  When I list the topics using
topic.  I think this issue should be reopened until the problem is properly diagnosed.
Whoops, I am very sorry for the irritations. Apparently I had the GUI already running when I did the tests. It pollutes the results as it subscribes to the topic.

Just did a quick check on the topics and the code and it appears there is actually a bug as the nodeinterface no longer publishes information about the nodes on /statistics_node. (have to verify this though)
I will try to resolve this in the next days but I cannot guarantee it. Thus if any of you guys has any hints - I'm happy to merge any PR that fix this.
thanks for reopening, at the moment I don't know enough about this package to propose a viable solution in the form of a PR.
I've made some quick test and log some info.
It looks like self._id is not in node_api[2] and there is no instances of NodeStatisticsHandler.
I ran it on Ubuntu virtual machine in the following way:
I hope this may help you. Sorry, if it is not.
returns an array that does not contain the uri of the node, it returns the following:
The subsequent check in the code fails since the ip of the machine is not in that list.  I commented out that check and the node then started publishing the
I've created an issue in the

cd ~/catkin_ws/
catkin clean
catkin build
rosrun rqt_gui rqt_gui

Not that I know, but which ROS and Ubuntu versions are you running? We currently support 14.04 with indigo and 16.04 with kinetic. Those compile well on a fresh Travis CI system, so there should not be any special activities beyond installing all dependencies.

Should we be forcing blue to be fixed at the origin in Gazebo with the world joint?
That stops the model from being moved around which might be inconvenient if people want to simulate the robot somewhere else in a simulated world.

Humm yes, that's true. Without fixing the robot to the world frame the robot tends to float away in the zero gravity world. We have the zero gravity gazebo world to simulate the control interface a user would have, where the hardware interface provides the gravity compensation.
I agree though that it is inconvenient. Maybe we can add a parameter that allows the user to choose if they want the extra joint?
Perhaps we should move towards re-enabling gravity in the Gazebo world?
It might be a little less clean for use on the real robot, but one option would be to move the gravity compensation code from the controller manager level to the controller level.
Alright sounds good. I've gone ahead and made these two pull requests which should address this.
Let me know what you all think!

issue_title: specifying LaserScanAngularBoundsFilter can result in *the wrong points* being removed
issue_contents: The filters package requires plugins to be specified with their package name as a prefix:
If this is not the case, such as e.g.
and pick the last one that
(not has the exact) name (see link above).
Now what could possibly go wrong after
came along in 2014 and added a
filter that has exactly the opposite behavior of
Until they renamed the filter to
Since then, this kind of (heavily outdated but otherwise fully functional) style of restricting the LaserScan
will make laser_filters autocomplete the type to
As a result the PR2 at the moment
thanks for describing in detail how this happens! This should have been happening for quite a while, right? Did this just start happening on PR2s?

Since renaming filters now could break other things, and there are lots of robots besides the PR2, I'm not crazy about that. Likewise making the plugin finding logic stricter to require package names would likely break lots and lots of existing configurations. I would say we should add a warning, but there already is one, right?

So are there any changes you'd like to see to laser_filters as a result of this problem? It seems to me that the solution is for the PR2 code to get fixed, and for people to heed the warning that is already there.

One possible fix: we could error out in the case that multiple plugins contain the filter name from the yaml. I suppose that would only break robots that already have a config that could be breaking things.
Also, what version of ROS are PR2s running these days? Is it a version still built by the buildfarm?
There is a ... partially incomplete ... indigo release of the PR2 that got released by Clearpath.
This is one of the things that are still wrong there. As you can see above, I just filed a request with the PR2 repo too. So yes, obviously this should be fixed there.
However, due to the bizarre nature of this error, I wanted to point it out to this repo too.
I believe it would be a good idea to make the filters package more strict in the matching in ROS lunar+,
but I don't see any good way to resolve this problem for indigo to kinetic either.
Since the plugin finding code is in the filters package, I've created an issue there as well:
Filter finding in the filters package has now been updated to require the package name and exact filter name. When the PR2s are updated to Lunar, there will at least be a better error message

issue_contents: topic simply switches control of the robot back to the user (after the robot has entered the

). It would be nice if, on top of this, the robot also backs up slowly for a short distance. Similar to how the built-in cleaning behaviours work when starting on a docking station. Unfortunately, iRobot has not exposed this undocking behaviour, so we have to roll our own.
Could you not write a simple program which just drives backward and then turns for 180 degrees?
Could you not write a simple program which just drives backward and then turns for 180 degrees?
Yes. I was debating whether or not it should be a routine inside

, but I think it is better to only expose the underlying interface provided by the Create/Roomba platforms. Perhaps, an undocking routine could be implemented in a separate node as an optional feature in

I would go for having them separate. I think the whole Docking/Undocking process should be done via an Action Server. You could preempt your requests and also cover all the specific cases (ex: if ordered to undock while already docked/charging - backup and rotate, if ordered to undock while still searching for the charger - stop and return control to user, etc ). This of course if you don't mind the overhead and added code complexity.

Thanks for the input. I like the idea of an action server for docking. If we want to follow the OI Spec more exactly there could be an action server for each of the possible "demos" that the base provides (ie.
). Unfortunately there does not seem to be a notion of "done" for the actions I mentioned coming from the base. It may be simpler to leave the
interface as is and have the
feature for regaining control of the robot. For example, changing the mode to FULL via a message (or service call) to
will naturally preempt a docking procedure. We can add complexity in a separate package with an undocking behaviour.
For docking at least we could query the charging state of the robot. If the base gets to the charger and starts charging then the action is complete.

issue_title: Serial Freezing after a long time - then unfreezing
issue_contents: We have been using this package successfully - except that after the create 2 has been in the charger for a long time, it seems to become either partially or fully unresponsive. By taking it off the charger by hand, or by sending it random combinations of of FULL/PASSIVE commands and /UNDOCK commands, it seems to sometimes become fully responsive after a minute or two but not always.
Expected behavior: We should just send it an /undock command which puts it into full mode and it should start responding to movement commands.

Actual behavior: When it is in this mode, we are sending in an /undock command and it is not showing a toggled /mode or /battery/charging_state in the ROS topic outputs and does not drive around or go beep, etc.
We have seen this across 3 Create 2's, multiple USB-> Serial cables and multiple computers so it doesn't seem to be a state of the hardware but instead something core to the system.

I have been running this for 4 days (over the weekend) and could see our code internally toggling passive / full every few minutes but then tried to undock it and back it up and it would not come out of the passive mode when I sent a FULL command.
Below I can see that there 9M packets which have been sent. When it was not responding, this number was staying constant for a while then jerking up then flat.
After toggling things for a while, I started to see it incrementing again by 60 packets / s and it was fully responsive (No ROS reset, unplugging, moving off the charger, etc).

Thanks for reporting this. I can't recall myself experiencing this issue, but I have not had the driver running continuously for days. To clarify, does this issue only present itself when the robot is charging (or just coming off of an extended charge)?

Only when it is charging. We have actually isolated it to 2 things. 1) hardware flow control has to be on to trigger the keep alive on the create USB cable or it goes to sleep after 5 min. This is not enabled in libcreate. 2) we have found that when it toggles from full to passive and then charges, we are the packets dying right at that point which says it could be a power thing on our setup. When we toggle it a few times more, it comes back with packets so it is the serial connection resetting.
But a key change would be to enable hardware flow control.

To clarify here, there is one thing that should change on create_autonomy/libcreate. flow control needs to be changed from none to hardware for the BTC wire to trigger a wake up if the create has gone to sleep.
Separately, it seems there could be a hardware communications weakness on the create 2 which I have documented here and also contacted irobot (

) for help on as we have narrowed in the information to an exact point in time where communication fails independent of which create 2 (we tried 3), computer (tried 2 NUC's, 1 Mac laptop) and communications protocol (Tried Create Autonomy and also echoing packets in on command line).
contents_details_more: Using the USB --> Serial cable that comes with the create 2
Toggling into FULL mode and back to PASSIVE every 4 minutes to try to make sure it doesn't go asleep (A hack based on forum posts)

We have seen the Create start in sleep mode (Booted computer 20 minutes before, then started it - and it was frozen from the beginning. We have also had it start in regular mode where it seems to get stuck, even when we are triggering a change in states to full every 4 minutes (Well within the 5 minute limit)
Is Create Autonomy sending in the wake up command and other elements to toggle it back awake? Is there something I am missing?
Have other people encountered it freezing after a while.
Is there a command we should be sending in separately to keep the robot from going to sleep "hard" when in passive mode rather than toggling to FULL then PASSIVE again?

Can it be anything to do with the baudrate the systems are suppose to communicate in?

for instructions). The Create communicates with 57600 or 19200 (default) baud.

The solution in this case was a fix in
I am unable to reproduce this issue with a Create 1 platform on Ubuntu 18.04, but I would be willing to accept
if others on this thread can confirm it fixes the issue for them.

issue_contents: hi , someone knows how restart odometry ?
What do you mean by "restart odometry"?

If you are looking for a way to reset the published odometry values to zero, there is no feature to do this other than restarting the driver. I think it would be reasonable to add a ROS service to trigger a reset. I'm happy to review any contributions!

issue_title: Specify transmission-related syntax in URDF and YAML
issue_contents: . While the syntax for transmissions themselves is

, we need to establish the appropriate syntax for sensors linked to joints vs actuators. We also need to handle multi-speed transmissions, and therefore the associated actuator that shifts gears (Typically a solenoid for 2 speed gearboxes. What about more than 2 speed?)

. We require a generic custom transmission that allows for a variable number of inputs and outputs to be linked. A typical use case would be drive trains; A 4-CIM 6-wheel skid steer would require a 2-in 3-out transmission for each side of the drive base.

Typically, all inputs will be equal, and all outputs will be equal, with a specific reduction between them. (Think WCP gearboxes). We may want to support having independant gear reduction for each input and output, though this is not a priority and would likely be more involved.

. Many teams use multi-speed gearboxes. For now, we will focus on 2-speed gearboxes, as those are most common in FRC. AFAIK, ros_contol transmissions do not typically support multiple, selectable reductions. We need to develop custom transmissions that allow for this behaviour. We need to be able to:
a) Define each gear reduction (probably in the URDF)
b) Allow an actuator (eg. a DigitalInput or Solenoid) to be specified as the 'gear selector'.
c) Add logic to switch gear reduction based on the 'gear selector'
In order to maintain feature parity with simulation, this must also be implemented in Gazebo, which may be a significant hurdle. Will need to do more research.

In order to work with generic servos, we need to have additional configuration when we specify the servo in the YAML file. This likely includes optional values for min angle (default=0), max angle (default=180), and perhaps min PWM (default 0.4ms) and max PWM (default 2.4 ms) timing.

Note: These defaults match the defaults specified by the WPILib (Which match the configuration for the Hitec HS-322HD servo provided in the Kit of Parts in 2008). We should maintain these same defaults, so that the default behaviour in our package will match the default behaviour when using the standard WPILib.

We require a driver station for 2 purposes; First, it will be required for running the robot in simulation, since the official NI driver station is only for real robots. Additionally, since code will be developed in Ubuntu, it would be nice to have the ability to drive real robots from Ubuntu as well. Since the NI driver station is Windows only, we need our own.
is no longer supported, which is a shame since it would have been trivial to add a ROS wrapper around. We may pick up support of this one day, but for the time being it's not required.
This driver station should be build using
, and will just publish joystick and game data for the rest of the system, mimicking the behaviour of the real robot.

Create QT app layout as a
file, mimicking the real driver station as closely as possible
Publish enabled/disabled, teleop/auto, match time, etc
Read from USB joysticks and publish their data

issue_title: Setup CI for both native and cross compilation
issue_contents: Currently, Travis only performs native builds. Not sure if it's possible, but it would be great if we could also test our cross builds. Might be able to use something like Qemu, but we need to be careful about not exceeding Travis's job time limit. I don't know if this is possible, but perhaps we could have a job for cross-compiling ROS and have Travis aggressively cache the result, and then run our cross-compile job against the cached result so that we don't need to rebuild ROS every time. Again, no idea if that's possible with Travis.
We should also download and build with all the supported 3rd party plugins enabled.
Instead of Qemu, this would probably be better with a custom Docker image equivalent to NI Linux-RT or the FRC RoboRIO image
Currently, we have no tests. Our CI just checks that the code builds and links properly, but doesn't test any of the code itself. We
This is an open-ended meta-issue. I'd like to leave it open and update it to track new issues until we have a decent coverage of our current codebase.
Feel free to comment below or open additional issues with tests that we should implement. I will update this meta-issue to track these tests.
contents_details_more: We don't have anything to track yet :(

issue_contents: Rather than having various documentation files in the repo, make a GitHub wiki and move all documentation files there.
Before the end of the year, we should get this stack indexed so that it's easy to install and use.
We should have some example robots with example URDFs, YAML files, and launch files in the repo. We should create some kind of dedicated example package to contain these.
will have to act as an example.

issue_title: Publish joystick data from Driver Station
issue_contents: While perhaps less important for our autonomous application, one of the most critical features of the driver station is the ability to interface with USB gamepads and pass the data to the robot.
These will be published in an array of
msgs, wrapped in a msg that also contains a few bonus fields such as each stick's name and HIDType.

This should be done in a fashion as similar to the real driver station as possible. We want up to 6 USB joysticks, re-orderable in the UI, with a gamepad-viewer debug tool for the currently selected stick. We should take care to ensure that our button, axis, and POV enumeration is identical to that of the NI Driver Station, so that we don't get weirdness when going back and forth.
One hiccup to this parity is the fact that the

messages do not contain POV hats, only axes and buttons. My suggestion is to append the POV hat state in both the axis and button arrays, since it's kinda neither but also kinda both. Alternatively/additionally, we could pass either info about the POV (ie. "The POV is mapped to axes 4 and 5, as well as buttons 6, 7, 8, and 9") and/or the POV itself alongside the joystick messages.
The WPILib offers the ability to send haptic feedback to the controllers. We would like to support this. Each joystick is given two 'rumble' values, an unsigned 16bit integer for each left and right.
These will be wrapped in a message of two
arrays, one for left and one for right, and published from the robot. The driver station will need to subscribe to these and apply it to the gamepads.

Before the end of the year, we need to determine the best way to migrate to exclusively use Python 3.
files outputted by cmake during compilation. Unfortunately, this means that
a) code must always be compiled before running clang-tidy
b) code that is not compiled (For example, files specific to real HW) are not analyzed

In addition, simply cross-compiling and then running the clang-tidy script causes the tool to get confused by the cross-compilation and report tons of irrelevant errors as well as misreporting true errors.

Should add a 3x3 covariance matrix to all IMU hardware templates. When specifying an IMU in the config file, a 3x3 covariance matrix should be added for each of the sensors that the IMU contains. For example, the built-in accelerometer should only contain a covariance matrix for linear acceleration. By contrast, the NavX and Pigeon IMUs should contain covariance matrices for each angular velocity, linear acceleration, and orientation (magnetometer).

issue_contents: The Wiki is missing a write up on how to use the passive SONAR.  Readme of passive SONAR has legacy command of: "rosrun mil_passive_sonar sonar.launch."

The overhaul of the passive sonar system was put on hold after there were hardware issues with Jake's board and there were plans for a new board to be created. Now that we have a functional way to interact with the old Paul board,

and I will write an interface to make it compatible with that board. Until this is complete, I recommend checking out an older version of the SubjuGator repository to get a functional sonar package as follows:
issue_code:
git clone https://github.com/uf-mil/SubjuGator
cd SubjuGator
git reset --hard 0089e68b9f48b96af9c3821f356e3a487841e87e

issue_title: Write tool to recover camera pose using LIDAR
issue_contents: On NaviGator, we have a pretty accurate transform from our GPS/INS to the LIDAR because it is rigidly mounted with simple geometry (the CAD model tells us). However, the camera transforms were measured and likely have significant error. It is mathematically possible to recover the pose of the camera in the LIDAR frame by identifying the same features in a LIDAR pointcloud and an image frame. This would improve our transforms.
I can work on this one! I've done alot of LIDAR registration in the past, I'll certainly look into LIDAR/Optical image registration!
Current method of brute forcing through a list of bags does not work to the well.

General idea would be to have a python script that will read a directory, loop through all the bags, open them using rospy bag, and then save some basic information into a HTML file (such as a list of topics). A quality of life thing would be detect if there was a camera topic, and then load an image frame and save it so that it appears in the HTML alongside the bag name.
So you can see a description / usage guide for a task. Either static (written to ROS param) or dynamic (call a service, may change based on status).

issue_title: PCODAR: errode old objects and points
contents_details_more: If objects are currently within field of view, but have not been seen (new points associated) recently (configurable time), remove the object. This is useful, for example, when a kayak moves by the boat and then leaves.
If an object is currently seen (in view and new points associated), remove older points associated with that object. This will allow the object to "move" over time if it drifts without "smearing"

issue_contents: Refactors for the passive sonar system. Some of these will be pushed upstream to Sylphase's passive sonar system:

Collect bags with raw data to experiment with improving the system

issue_contents: Write a generic interface for thruster mapping in 3D (body wrench to individual thrust efforts). Some ideal features
contents_details_more: Option to parse URDF file to find  thrusters (joints identified for a prefix THRUSTER_)
Inheritance based for other minimization functions (minimize energy, faster processing, etc)
Function to disable/enable on the fly (when thrusters are broken, etc)
